Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Exploring the Invisible Universe With Milky Way Dwarfs and Streams
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Willman will use Milky Way stellar streams and dwarf galaxies to study the Galaxy's dark matter sub-halos and formation history. She will implement a photometric technique to mitigate contamination from unresolved galaxies in Sloan Digital Sky survey and Dark Energy Survey point source catalogs. She will apply new techniques to optical (Sloan Digital Sky Survey, Dark Energy Survey) and infrared (UKIDSS) datasets to study known stellar streams with higher fidelity and to reveal the presence of previously unseen streams and dwarfs in previously unmapped Milky Way volume. The data are already publicly available for both the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and UKIDSS. The Dark Energy Survey is scheduled to begin survey operations in 2012. Dr. Willman will also use N-body and N-body + SPH simulations to explore a possible new method to "see" purely dark sub-halos. She will investigate the merging histories of the Milky Way's dwarf galaxies and possible observational signatures thereof. This work provides a direct approach to astronomically measure the properties of dark matter on the smallest possible sub-galactic scales - a major problem facing observational cosmology. It will also leave the field well-poised for the upcoming wide-field optical and infrared surveys.

A postdoctoral researcher and undergraduate students will be trained as they participate in this research and in related public outreach. The postdoctoral researcher will also engage in closely mentored undergraduate teaching experiences at Haverford College. Dr. Willman will lead an undergraduate seminar in science diversity in Years 1, 3, and 5. Students and Dr. Willman will collaborate on developing Haverford's student-run Strawbridge Observatory public program. Numerous undergraduates will have the opportunity to participate in a student-led research program based on KPNO 0.9m telescope observations. Dr. Willman will also release star catalogs for the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and the Dark Energy Survey informed by broad-band photometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The program CAREER: Exploring the Invisible Universe with Milky Way Dwarfs and Streams used stellar streams and dwarf galaxies, around the Milky Way and beyond, to investigate the questions What is the nature of dark matter? and What is the formation history of the Milky Way?

This program contributed to 35 scientific publications.  Twenty-three of these publications are in refereed journals, two of which were led by undergraduate students at Haverford College. Twelve of these publications were conference poster presentations at American Astronomical Society (AAS) meetings, six of which were led by undergraduate students at Haverford College and one was led by a high school student.

The Intellectual Merits of this grant have included

  • Discovery of the most distant stars known to be associated with the Milky Way, which influences our understanding of the formation of the Galaxy (Bochanski et al 2014a, Bochanski et al 2014b, Sanderson et al. 2016);
  • New predictions for the numbers and distributions of dwarf galaxies around the Milky Way (Hargis et al 2014), and around dwarf irregular (Dooley et al 2017a and 2017b);
  • Demonstration of RR Lyrae as a tool for the discovery of previously unseen Milky Way dwarf galaxies (Baker & Willman 2015) and to study the properties of two Milky Way ultra-faint dwarfs (Boettcher et al 2013, Garling et al 2017);
  • Demonstration of new evidence of the impact of the Milky Way’s gravitational field on the observed properties of ultra-faint dwarf galaxies and the remnants thereof (Hargis et al 2016, Collins et al 2017, Garling et al 2017); and
  • Discovery of two new dwarf galaxy companions to dwarf galaxies (NGC 2403 and NGC 3109) themselves, demonstrating that dwarf galaxy satellites exist in many environments and opening a new window for disentangling the degenerate effects of environment, feedback, and gravity on the formation of the Universe's tiniest galaxies (Sand et al 2015, Carlin et al 2016).

The Broader Impacts of this grant have included

  • The development and implementation of a new seminar at Haverford College, The Persistent Lack of Diversity in the Sciences;
  • Expansion of Haverford College’s outreach program to be inclusive of a broad range of student outreach leaders and to attract hundreds of visitors each year;
  • Training three postdoctoral researchers (John Bochanski – professor at Rider College, Jonathan Hargis – staff member at STScI, Jeffrey Carlin – research scientist at LSST);
  • Training four post baccalaureate, graduate, and post graduate students (Ragadeepika Pucha – graduate student at the University of Arizona, Brian Kimmig – computer science graduate student at the University of Utah, Annie Preston – computer science student at the University of California at Davis, Shane Walsh – LBT service observer); and
  • Training dozens of undergraduate students in public outreach and/or astronomical research, including a balance of men and women with diverse representation across socioeconomic and ethnic backgrounds.
